0.text:
Donald Trump won the presidential campaign
by breaking all the rules, and so it’s tempting

4.text:
to imagine that the rules no longer applied
to him.

9.text: That he could do things no one had done before.

11.text:
Well, we’re now about 100 days into Trump’s
presidency, and we’re learning, and maybe

16.text:
more importantly he is learning, that what
works in a campaign, when your strategy is

20.text:
get the most TV time possible, it doesn’t
really work when you’re governing.

24.text:
And there’s a lesson here, a lesson for
Trump and a lesson for those who will come

27.text:
after him: The campaign might be turning into
a reality TV show, but governing still isn’t.

32.text:
The same things Trump did to win attention
as a candidate, and to show he wasn’t a

36.text:
normal politician, that’s what’s breaking
him as a president.

39.text:
It’s worth digging deep into his record
so far.

42.text:
Health care, Trump’s top priority, it crashed
and burned, and it crashed and burned because

47.text:
Trump didn’t understand the American Health
Care Act.

49.text:
He didn’t know what his legislation did,
he didn’t seem to realize it broke almost

53.text:
all of his promises, it was wildly unpopular,
and he didn’t have a good argument to make

58.text:
He didn’t get the the legislative maneuvering
needed to pass it.

61.text:
So he ended up endorsing an incredibly, incredibly
unpopular piece of legislation and then declared

69.text:
I have milk that lasted longer than Trump’s
health care bill.

72.text:
And yeah, he keeps talking about bringing
it back, but he still doesn’t have a strategy,

75.text:
he has no new ideas to make it more popular
or make it a better bill, and doesn’t even

80.text:
seem to understand why the first bill failed
in the first place.

83.text:
Perhaps because of all that, Trump is historically,
incredibly unpopular.

86.text:
Less than three months into his presidency,
he is less popular than Obama was at any point.

91.text:
To underscore how dubious of an achievement
he has here, Trump is more unpopular with

96.text:
unemployment at 4.7 percent than Obama was
when unemployment was 10 percent.

101.text:
It took President George W. Bush a disastrous
war to hit Trump’s current polling nadir.

106.text:
This makes everything else Trump wants to
achieve harder — vulnerable congressional

109.text:
Republicans have little political incentive
to back a president this unpopular on a hard

115.text:
Trump’s most consequential executive orders
are stuck in the courts and imperiled by his

120.text:
So far, Trump’s most unusual and controversial
policy change is his executive order banning

124.text:
travelers from a number of majority-Muslim
countries.

126.text:
But the slapdash first iteration of that order
was stopped by the courts, and the substantially

131.text:
scaled-back sequel suffered the exact same
fate.

134.text:
And the biggest problem here, the reason his
executive orders keep getting stopped by the

140.text: It is the things Trump himself said.

141.text:
TRUMP: “Donald J. Trump is calling for a
total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering

149.text:
And, for that matter, the things his surrogates
say he said.

151.text:
Giuliani: “So when he first announced it,
he said 'Muslim ban.'

157.text: Show me the right way to do it legally.'

160.text:
Having said he wanted an (unconstitutional)
Muslim ban and then having Rudy Giuliani confirm

163.text:
it on television, it’s difficult for Trump
to now convince the courts that the policies

167.text:
descending from that promise are not targeting
Muslims.

172.text:
Trump’s administration, meanwhile, is historically
understaffed.

176.text:
Critical positions ranging from chief economist
to undersecretary of state remain unfilled,

181.text:
and so large swaths of the executive branch
are operating without direction, oversight,

187.text:
This is why there’s something comic about
Trump appointing his son-in-law to lead a

190.text:
task force on improving government: To build
a better government, first you need to understand

194.text: how to work the one you’ve got.

196.text:
Trump’s key staff have also dissolved into
infighting and factionalism; they are leaking

202.text:
You have a war  between the conservative
wing of the Trump administration — led by

206.text:
the often-squabbling Reince Priebus and Steve
Bannon — they’re trying to head off a

210.text:
power play from the New York business wing
of the Trump administration, led by Jared

213.text:
Kushner and ex–Goldman Sachs vice president
Gary Cohn.

217.text:
Bannon is losing power fast, it seems, and
the amount of leaking and ass covering both

222.text: sides of this battle are doing is intense.

224.text:
This does not bode well for the White House’s
internal processes or functioning.

228.text:
Trump’s administration is, of course, also
under investigation, as is his campaign, his

233.text: associates, and there are already casualties.

235.text:
It was weird, during the election, to watch
Russia helping Trump, and being helped by

239.text:
Trump, and to have the media treat it all
as a curious sideshow.

242.text:
But that’s over now, and the fallout has
already consumed National Security Adviser

246.text:
Michael Flynn, probably Trump’s most dangerous
and abnormal key aide.

250.text:
Flynn, by the way, is now seeking an immunity
deal from federal prosecutors and Congress

258.text:
One of the strangest pieces of Trump’s presidency
is how much he has backpedaled on the major

264.text:
Everything that set him apart, that made him
a populist, he’s just throwing it away.

268.text:
Remember when he was going to cover everybody
with health care?

271.text: This is an un-Republican thing for me to say.

274.text: I am going to take care of everybody.”

275.text: Yeah his bill didn’t do that.

277.text:
Remember when he was going to brand China
a currency manipulator?

280.text: He had been talking about that for years.

281.text:
Trump: “They are the single biggest currency
manipulator that’s ever been on this planet.”

286.text:
And then he became president and haha, just
kidding.

289.text:
Remember when he was going to avoid fights
like Syria, he criticized Obama for drawing

292.text: the red line in the first place?

297.text: There is no upside and tremendous downside.

300.text:
Save your powder for another (and more important)
day!”

304.text:
-We are just getting in some video of US strikes
in Syria.

308.text: Turns out he just hadn’t thought it through.

310.text:
In some cases, these flip-flops represent
Trump coming to a more grounded position,

316.text:
But the fact that he has no coherent philosophy
of governance, and his ideas are so weakly

320.text:
held, that they’re this easily changed — that’s
bad, that’s evidence of how unpredictable

326.text: How little the president himself knows.

329.text: And that can lead to real disaster.

331.text:
The other problem Trump is facing is he has
no magic fix for the GOP’s internal tensions.

335.text:
It is striking how taken aback he was by the
resentments and factionalism splitting House

340.text: Republicans during the health care debate.

341.text:
TRUMP: “I like Speaker Ryan; he worked very,
very hard.

344.text:
A lot of different groups, he’s got a lot
of factions, and there’s been a long history

349.text:
of liking and disliking even within the Republican
Party, long before I got here."

354.text:
What you just heard Trump say there is a sign
of how weakened he is.

358.text:
His White House is even worrying they won’t
be able to prevent a government shutdown even

361.text:
though their party holds complete control
of Congress.

363.text: Look, take a step back here.

365.text:
Imagine I’d had told you a few months ago
that America would soon elect an unpopular,

368.text:
undisciplined, inexperienced, scandal-plagued
reality television star to the presidency,

372.text:
and that he would staff his White House with
warring advisers who had never worked in government

376.text:
and who would spend their time trying to undercut
each other.

379.text:
You probably would have predicted a presidency
that looks very much like the one we have

384.text:
Which isn’t to say Trump hasn’t accomplished
anything, much less that he won’t.

387.text:
Neil Gorsuch got confirmed to the Supreme
Court, for instance, and a number of Trump’s

390.text:
executive orders are consequential — his
recent climate change directives in particular.

395.text:
And if nothing else, Trump prevented Hillary
Clinton from taking office and turning the

399.text:
Supreme Court Democratic for the first time
in a generation.

402.text:
As one Republican Hill staffer said to me,
“If we get Gorsuch and avoid a nuclear war,

407.text: a lot of us will count this as a win."

409.text:
And look, fair enough, but what we’re learning,
day by day, is there’s no magic to Trump.

413.text:
When he does things people hate, he becomes
unpopular.

416.text:
When he backs bad legislation and bad processes
—the bills fail.

419.text:
Trump has not found a shortcut for American
politics.

421.text:
To succeed at a hard job, he has to work hard
in ways and at tasks that he has, until now,

427.text:
shown little aptitude for and less interest
in.

430.text:
Trump himself may never be a normal president,
but the system he leads remains more normal

436.text:
You can imagine scenarios where that changes
— a terrorist attack, for instance — but

440.text:
the fact remains that so far, incompetence,
not autocracy, has defined the Trump administration.

445.text:
He has achieved much less than his predecessors
at this point in their terms, and he has done

449.text: so at great cost to his own popularity.

452.text:
It is possible, of course, Trump will yet
recover.

455.text:
But it is also possible he’ll enter a failure
loop, where his unpopularity and his scandals

459.text:
and his failed initiatives and his poor management
lead to more public anger and more aggressive

463.text:
congressional investigation and more failed
initiatives and more fracturing and infighting

468.text:
The 2018 elections are a long way away, but
Donald Trump is off to a very bad start.
